message_text: Praising your children
PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme
Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.
We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves! 

Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:

1. Be positive
2. Be specific
3. Be enthusiastic

To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "3". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 1. Be positive

Praise @fields.child_nickname for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

Step 1. Be positive

Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 2. Be specific

Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, @fields.child_nickname,' instead of 'Good job.'

Step 2. Be specific

Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'

Step 3. Be enthusiastic

Really mean it when you say it! The more real you are the better it will feel.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about praise:

1. Be positive
2. Be specific
3. Be enthusiastic

You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

@fields.age_group_for_tips
Here is a comic on praising your teen.

Parent: “Thank you for being quiet while I talked to my boss. I appreciate it! Here, you can use my phone to WhatsApp your friends”

(1)

Teen: “Thanks! I really want to see how they are doing.”

(2)
Here is a comic on praising your child.

Silence 

(1)

Parent: “Thank you for playing quietly while I was doing work. In 5 minutes I will be able to join you.”

(2)

Parent: “I really appreciate you playing quietly together while I worked. Now I can play with you for a bit. What would you like to do?”

(3)

Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!
